These include lactase, which aids in digestion, and immunoglobulins that support the immune system.

Studies have shown that raw milk is rich in bioactive compounds, such as conjugated linoleic acid (CLA), which has been associated with reduced inflammation and improved metabolic health. Additionally, raw milk contains a diverse range of naturally occurring bacteria, many of which are probiotic and contribute to gut health, aiding in digestion and enhancing nutrient absorption.

In fact, many traditional cultures have consumed raw milk for generations without the health issues we see today in modern populations. The emphasis on pasteurization has been driven by industrial agriculture concerns, not by sound public health science.

In conclusion, raw milk not only preserves the natural integrity of the milk but also provides a more complete and health-promoting nutritional profile than its pasteurized counterpart.
